conclusion: To compare the average velocities of Car A and Car B during the time interval from t=0 to t=t1, we need to calculate the average velocity for each car over that time period.
The velocity-time graph for Car A is shown in the figure. From t=0 to t=t1, the velocity of Car A is given by the slope of the line segment AB.
The slope of the line segment AB is the change in velocity divided by the change in time. Therefore, the average velocity of Car A is: Average velocity of Car A = (v2 - v1) / (t1 - t0)
The velocity-time graph for Car B is shown in the figure. From t=0 to t=t1, the velocity of Car B is given by the slope of the line segment AC.
The slope of the line segment AC is the change in velocity divided by the change in time. Therefore, the average velocity of Car B is: Average velocity of Car B = (v1 - v2) / (t1 - t0)
To compare the average velocities of Car A and Car B, we can set up the equation: (v2 - v1) / (t1 - t0) = (v1 - v2) / (t1 - t0)
Since the numerator and denominator of both sides of the equation are equal, we can simplify the equation to: v2 - v1 = v1 - v2
Therefore, the average velocity of Car A is equal to the average velocity of Car B.
Final answer: The average velocities of Car A and Car B are equal during the time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
